 KINGDOM OF MOROCCO SOCIAL PRIORITIES PROGRAM BASIC HEALTH PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. SOCIAL SECTOR BACKGROUND AND ISSUES A. Economic Context 1.01 Over the past decade, Morocco has instituted reforms designed to achieve macroeconomic stability and to liberalise the economy. Wide-reaching and comprehensive, the reforms have gradually moved Morocco away from a predominantly state-administered economy towards one that is more market-driven and outward-oriented. Yet, progress achieved on the macroeconomic front remains fragile, as demonstrated by the continued indebtedness, and the deterioration in the fiscal and external accounts which were exarcerbated by the 1995 drought. 1.02 Morocco's growth rate, which averaged about 4% annually during the last decade, fell well below expectations and was too low to absorb the country's growing labor force. Private investment and domestic saving rates remain modest; labor productivity is not increasing; and international competitiveness has recently eroded. The situation has been further exacerbated by the recent drought, but prospects for 1996 are brighter. Despite significant recent progress, performance has also been disappointing in the social sectors. Morocco's indicators in health, education, literacy, and access to safe water continue to lag behind those of economically comparable countries. A fifth of the population still lives in poverty or near-poverty, urban unemployment rates have reached 20%, and rural women are still economically and socially marginalized. 1.03 Morocco's low social performance and its relative economic success are intimately related. For even with constructive political and economic reforms in place, the country cannot reach and sustain higher economic growth rates without a substantial accumulation of human capital. To achieve such a reserve, it must boost its investment in the provision of basic social services. Conversely, without sustained economic growth, it will be extremely difficult to improve substantially employment opportunities and living conditions of its population, which already stands at 26 million and is growing apace. B. Poverty 1.04 Data gathered from the 1985 Household Consumption Survey and the 1991 Living Standards Measurement Survey (LSMS) showed that the share of Morocco's population living below the poverty line fell from 21 to 13% in those six years, while the GNP per capita rose by about 30% (and presently hovers at around US$ 1,1 00). This performance was achieved during the period of structural adjustment. Adding the number of those whose expenditure levels are just above the poverty line to the number of those who live below it, more than 3.3 million Moroccans are poor enough to be isolated from the mainstream economy.
 - 2 - 1.05 Urban, rural, and regional variations are also striking, and the gap dividing them is deepening. In 1991, 72% of all poor lived in rural areas as compared to 70% six years earlier. Likewise, while a quarter of the population lived in poverty in the Center-North, East, and Center- South regions, the poverty rate was below 5 % in coastal areas. In rural areas, the poor are typically either seasonally underemployed wage-earners or small-scale farmers. In urban areas they are mostly self-employed people who work in the informal sector, underpaid (often temporary) wage- earners, or are unemployed. If access to basic social services is taken into account, still more differences between urban and rural areas come to light. 1.06 Along with low pay, unemployment and underemployment are major determinants of poverty. In the early 1990s, the aggregate unemployment rate in urban areas was estimated at 16 to 20%, but among the urban poor the unemployment rate reached 30%. Unemployment rates are much lower in rural areas, but these areas suffer substantial, chronic underemployment. Not surprisingly unemployment is most widespread among those with little or no education, but neither are those with a secondary education immune. Unemployment rates are higher for women overall. 1.07 The growing importance of the informal sector--although a sign of the economy' s dynamism and ability to absorb excess labor supply and react to demand--reflects an increase in the reservoir of persons prone to fall below the poverty threshold. The poverty assessment report (World Bank 1994) found a strong link between poverty in economic terms and such social ills as low literacy, education, health, and nutrition levels and high fertility rates. That report, and other studies, also found a strong correlation between income levels and degree of access to basic social services. In light of these findings, the report strongly recommends the rehabilitation of basic social services as a necessary prerequisite for the durable alleviation of poverty. Yet, until recently the various social policies and programs were not strongly coordinated, and the link between this disparate set of sectoral actions and the macroeconomic framework was loose. There was, moreover, no visible political will to address the problem of lagging social sector performance. C. Population, Health and Nutrition Population and health 1.08 As the other countries of the Maghreb, Morocco is in the midst of a demographic, epidemiologic, and social transition resulting from the diminution of the mortality rate from 19 per 1,000 in the 1960s to 7.3 per 1,000 in 1992 and a diminution in birth rates to 28.1 per 1,000. The annual population growth rate slowed from 2.8% for 1955-60 to 2.06% in 1982-1994. On the health front, transmissible diseases and maternal and child-related health problems are coming increasingly under control but still represent* an important burden of disease ("the unfinished agenda" as it is referred to in the epidemiologic transition), while the impact of chronic diseases is rising. In 1989, for instance, cardiovascular diseases caused one out of five deaths in Morocco. The country's successful priority health programs and improved lifestyles are responsible for these significant health gains. Over the last thirty years infant mortality has decreased from 119 to 61.6 per 1,000 and life expectancy at birth has increased from 45 to 65 years. 1.09 But despite these significant achievements, key indicators remain low. The maternal mortality rate is among the highest in Africa, averaging 332 per 100,000 as compared to 50 in Tunisia and 140 in Algeria. Inadequate handling of complicated deliveries is the main cause of death--not surprisingly, since only 40% of all deliveries take place in a medical setting (compared to 76% in Tunisia). Access to health facilities, evacuation procedures, and the medical referral system are deficient. Survey results also suggest that the prevalence of male health personnel is a possible
 -3- factor in Morocco's low use rates of maternal medical services. In addition, the fact that early neonatal deaths account for half of the infant mortality rate reflects the poor quality of services offered. Such potentially controllable infectious diseases as acute respiratory infections, diarrhea, measles, and meningitis are also among the leading causes of mortality and morbidity in children aged one to five. Tuberculosis, malaria and schistosomiasis are still non-negligeable features of morbidity, and poor hygiene and sanitation in the rural areas are a cause of serious concern. Although acquired immunodeficiency syndrome ( HIV/AIDS) is not yet a major problem, sexually transmitted diseases (which increase the risk of HIV infection) affect more than 7% of the population, according to a recent survey. 1.10 Morocco's population is expected to grow from 26 million currently to 33 million by 2007. At that time, the natural rate of increase will be 1.30%. The population under 15 would then represent a quarter of the population as against 38% now. Since 1968, family planning has been integrated into all development plans. In 1976 a division was created within the Ministry of Public Health (Ministere de la Sante Publique, MSP) to launch the VDMS program (visite a domicile de motivation systematique)--a major community outreach effort that subsequently led to the rapid development of family planning activities. This program and the increase of age at marriage, from 17.3 years in 1960 to 24 years in 1987, are responsible for the decrease in the total fertility rate (TFR) in Morocco from 7.4 to 3.6 children per woman. The modern contraceptive prevalence rate is now estimated at approximately 43%, with the pill being the most widely used method. The Government's objective for the year 2000 is to decrease the TFR to 2.6 children per woman. 1.11 Seven separate surveys have been carried out over a twenty-year period regarding the nutritional status of the population and Morocco has made significant efforts to deal with problems of food insecurity. The typical Moroccan diet's daily supply of calories (essentially from sugar, cereals, oils and other fats) would be adequate if food were equitably distributed. But as it now stands approximately 17% of children are wasted, stunted, or both. Children in the rural areas are at a clear disadvantage, and acute and chronic malnutrition are most prevalent in the South and Tensift regions. A 1989 infant mortality survey showed that malnutrition, associated with diarrhea, was the leading cause of death for children aged twenty-eight days to five years. It also showed significant gaps in the nutritional status of the urban versus the rural population, and men versus women. A 1994 national survey on iron and iodine deficiency found that 22% of children aged six to twelve were iodine deficient. Even more strikingly, 35.5% of children aged six months to five years and 45.5% of all pregnant women suffered from iron-deficiency anemia. A strategy to deal with iodine deficiency is presently being implemented with the assistance of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the African Development Bank (AfDB), and a strategy to address the problem of iron deficiency is being discussed (Annex 4). Organization of the health system 1.12 The national health system is organized around three sectors: public (MSP and Royal Army structures), semiprivate (mutuals and the CNSS, Caisse nationale de securite sociale, a network of twenty-three hospitals and clinics for government employees and their dependents) and private (about 2,550 private doctor's offices and 110 clinics). The private sector tends to be concentrated in major urban areas. The rural population relies almost entirely on the public sector for the provision of health care. 1.13 The MSP was reorganized in December 1994 and now includes seven directorates at the central level and sixty provincial delegations headed by physicians (Annex 1). Each provincial delegation includes an ambulatory unit staffed by a physician and nurses. This structure is
 -4 - responsible for all preventive and ambulatory care. But given the fact that MSP has until now been a highly centralized organization, the provincial level's actual contribution to planning has been quite limited so far, with the exception of some pilot experiences. 1.14 The public sector network includes about 1,650 basic health facilities (E0tablissements de Soins de Sante de Base, ESSBs), and 98 hospitals (provincial, regional, and university). The ESSBs include urban and rural dispensaries and health centers and represent the first interface of the population with the fixed facility system. They provide primary health care and handle deliveries, and all services are free of charge. In addition to the ESSBs, service coverage is provided by mobile clinics, outreach health workers, and in some remote areas, by traditional birth attendants (kablats). Major sector issues 1.15 Major sector issues include the inequity and inefficiency of the health system; the insufficient coverage of the rural population; the poor performance of the public health system, especially at the basic level; the situation in the pharmaceutical industry; insufficient financing to cover the rising cost of health care; and the centralization of management. 1.16 Inequity and inefficiency of the health system. Discrepancies between urban and rural areas and among regions are striking. The infant mortality rate is 65 per thousand in rural areas as opposed to 44 per thousand in urban areas; total fertility is 4.9 children per woman in rural areas compared to 2.2 in urban areas; and the under five mortality rate is 160 per thousand in the south, the poorest region of the country, as opposed to 66 per thousand in the center. Three-quarters of health personnel are concentrated in Rabat and Casablanca, where their services are underused. Morocco's better off citizens receive 40% of the MSP budget, the poorest receive less than 20% of this budget--translating into a per capita health expenditure which is 2.6 times greater in urban areas. The former therefore benefit more from the system. The hospital network, moreover, is mostly concentrated in the northeastern and central regions, and while all categories of health care personnel have significantly increased since 1960, 63% of physicians in the public sector are assigned to hospitals, with only 30% working in the ESSBs. The sector as a whole is poorly managed (as can be seen from its record of poor maintenance of equipment and infrastructure, waste, inadequate management and deployment of human resources, and poor logistics). By targeting Morocco's needy, the project would address the issue of inequity. It would also address the problem of inefficiency at the basic health level, since the hospital level is being dealt with by a separate Bank-funded project, under preparation (Health Management and Financing Project, FY97). 1.17 Insufficient coverage of the rural population. It is estimated that 37% of Moroccans use fixed public sector health facilities, and this number reaches 79% in lower-income groups and rural areas. By comparison, 52% of consultations are handled by private sector physicians. Data from the 1991 LSMS show that health care consumption is income elastic: the use rate is 64% among the 20% richest of the sample, as against 32% for the 20% lowest income group. While the coverage provided by the basic health network has significantly improved during the last decade, only 47% of the rural population now has access within six kilometers to fixed primary care facilities provided by the public sector, and no private facilities exist in the rural areas. Fourteen percent of rural people have no coverage, even in theory. This situation is not only caused by the inadequate distribution of health facilities and manpower between regions and in rural areas but also by their insufficient number overall. Approximately 53 % of the rural population, moreover, lives more than six kilometers away from an existing health care facility, which represents a major constraint to
 -5- access, especially that the private sector is not likely to expand significantly into the rural areas. The coverage provided by the mobile teams and outreach health workers (infifrmiers itinerants) is not functioning well, and the number of such workers has been diminishing significantly. The project would address these issues in the provinces targeted. 1.18 Poor quality within the basic health care system. The low credibility of the public health system largely explains its low rate of use. Curative care is virtually nonexistent, and visible and sustainable improvements in essential service delivery would be necessary to build the public's confidence in the ESSBs. During project preparation, a beneficiary assessment carried out in a sample of five of the provinces targeted under the project indicated that approximately half of the sample population was unhappy with the overall performance of public health facilities because of the lack of drugs, long waiting time, and poor staff attitude. As confirmed by surveys undertaken during project preparation, many facilities lack basic equipment and are poorly maintained. This accounts mainly for the low utilization of these services. Two-third of all public facility medical equipment have not been replaced in the last fifteen years. As confirmed by surveys undertaken during project preparation, the mobile clinics, too, are poorly equipped and organized, are not supervised, are poorly maintained, and resources to supervise and keep them functioning properly are lacking. 1.19 Health personnel, moreover, are not adequately deployed, are poorly motivated, and are not properly trained to deliver services. Because of lack of support from the MSP at the central and provincial levels, the number of outreach health workers is decreasing rapidly (there are barely a thousand left in the country). Mobile clinics and outreach workers, moreover, are not well integrated in the system and deliver in fact only a small portion of the essential services they are supposed to provide. Morocco's priority health programs are suffering from this situation. To give a few examples, the safe motherhood program is clearly lagging behind with only 45 % (as opposed to almost 60% in Tunisia) of pregnant women seeking prenatal care. Immunization coverage in rural areas has improved (to around 78%) but is still very insufficient. Emergency evacuations still do not exist, a situation which contributes to unacceptable levels of maternal, neonatal and infant mortality rates for a middle-income country such as Morocco. 1.20 Insufficient financing and rising cost of health care. Public sector financing accounts for 34% of total health expenditures in Morocco, NGOs and international aid for 4% and the private sector for 62%. Total health expenditures represent 3.8% of GDP (as compared to 4.9% in Tunisia and 7% in Algeria). Approximately 92% of public sector financing comes from MSP budget, which grew in real terms by 3.7% annually from 1960 to 1994. But if the effect of population growth is added to inflation, MSP's budget has been virtually stagnant during that period, averaging increases of only 1.3% a year. The MSP's share of government expenditures, moreover, decreased from 7.8% in 1960 to 2.9% in 1975, then rose again to 4.6 in 1994. About 75% of the MSP recurrent budget, moreover, goes to hospitals, which have no mechanisms to ensure better targeting of the needy population, which is eligible for free care. Expenditure on personnel represent 55 % of the MSP total budget. Health costs are defrayed by households, which contribute up to 50% of expenditures 1.21 Per capita health expenditure (less than US$40) is relatively low in Morocco when compared with that in other countries of similar economic development (such as Tunisia's US$100). Public expenditure is also distributed poorly within the sector and across regions and milieus. As Morocco enters an epidemiologic, demographic, and social transition, and as income increases, the demand for health care will be even greater. An aging population will demand more sophisticated medical technology and long-term care, both of which are costly. It will therefore be even more
 -6 - difficult for the Government to sustain the rising cost of health care. The MSP is presently conducting a study to analyze the changing situation in the sector (Maghreb Health Priorities Study FY96). At the same time a Health Management and Financing Project is being prepared in collaboration with the World Bank which will address financial as well as managerial issues. 1.22 The situation in the pharmaceutical sector. Morocco has a thriving pharmaceutical industry that produces a large quantity of drugs, covers over 80% of the country's pharmaceutical consumption and has started to export to other countries in the Region. The Moroccan industry, however, has been partly protected from international competition by high tariffs that have increased the cost of drugs to the population, and some firms have not achieved the level of quality of production that should be expected. Most of the pharmaceutical market is in the private sector, and serves wealthy and middle-class populations, as essential drugs often prove too expensive for the poor. The small public sector takes care of drug supply to primary care facilities and hospitals. Because of severe budget under-funding for essential drugs, Morocco has relied on external financing, including Bank loans, to finance a large share of public sector drug provision. This policy of financing basic operating costs through external assistance has proved a major disincentive for exploring other financing avenues, such as cost recovery, and has created a serious issue of sustainability in the medium and long term. 1.23 Morocco does not have a comprehensive pharmaceutical policy which guarantees reasonable access to essential drugs to the poor. Quality control and inspection have not performed adequately, and the drug pricing policy has favored the distribution of relatively expensive drugs in the private sector over that of cheap products. The recent reorganization of what used to be the Pharmacie Centrale (Central Pharmacy), under the umbrella of the MSP, has improved the overall management of stocks and MSP is committed to pursue this effort. However, logistics is still deficient and delays in the delivery of drugs to hospitals and the peripheral level are still more than a month, except for emergencies. Despite noticeable improvement in the procurement of drugs, the annual unique bidding process limits the possibilities to negotiate interesting prices. Because of these shortcomings, health facilities often face shortages and have to buy directly from local suppliers at a high price. The most serious problems in the public sector are the insufficient funding allocated through the budget and the inadequate intrasectoral allocation of resources for drugs among the different levels of health care, with hospitals taking the lion's share of drug allocations. In the early 1990's, the annual budget allocated to drugs and consumables was approximately 200 million of dirhams. This number has been decreasing recently, and hospitals use 36% of this budget. Per capita expenditures on drugs is estimated to US$23 of which US$1 comes from the public sector. During project preparation, the Bank funded a major pharmaceutical study. Agreement on actions to be taken in the sector was reached at negotiations [para.6.03 a(ii)]. 1.24 Centralization of management. An effective partnership between the central and provincial administrations does not currently exist. The provincial level, perceived as the implementing arm, has traditionally enjoyed little decisionmaking power, leaving little room for the initiatives and local adjustments necessary for the development of programs. Key aspects of personnel management are also centralized, an issue that will need to be dealt with if peripheral units are to manage their own personnel. The performance of rural health programs and services is also hampered by the lack of a locus for managing local health systems. Under the current arrangements, districts are widely dispersed and no intermediate level between province and district exists. With the recent reorganization (December 1994), the MSP is in the process of redefining the respective mandates of the central and provincial administrations, and defining the role of the MSP at each level of health care would be an important outcome of the Sectoral Action Plan. During negotiations, agreement was reached that mechanisms to strengthen provincial participation to planning of and decision-
 -7 - making for sector activities would be identified, submitted to the Bank and implemented by December 31, 1997 [para 6.03a (iii)]. II. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY AND BANK RESPONSE A. Government Strategy 2.01 For a long time in Morocco, spending to promote human capital was not considered an investment that would ultimately lead to greater and more sustainable economic growth, and instead, economic growth was perceived as the only engine of social progress. Therefore, social concerns were not a top Government priority, and--despite indisputable sectoral improvement during the 1980s and 1990s--there was no comprehensive, long-term plan for the social welfare of the country. 2.02 But following an era of thorough macroeconomic adjustment and worrisome decline in social conditions throughout the Kingdom, the Government has started to focus on social issues in a more concerted manner. In 1993 it issued the Social Development Strategy (Strategie de Developpement Social pour la Decennie 1990, SDS), which sets forth clear directives aimed at reversing past trends and establishing the framework for a sound social policy. Based on the 1991 Living Standards Measurement Survey, the Government strategy made extending basic social services to the poor and increasing their participation in economically productive activities its highest social goals. Such extended coverage would include access to safe water, sewage facilities, health care, family planning services, nutrition, primary education, literacy programs, and subsidized public housing. But recognizing prevailing budgetary constrainEs, the strategy stresses the inter- and intra-reallocation of resources and introduction of cost-recovery mechanisms. It also advocates action to promote employment and bolster social protection. Finally, the SDS emphasizes that a strong and appropriate administrative vehicle and reliable statistical monitoring system are required for the implementation of its recommendations. 2.03 The Government gave the first version of the Strategie de Developpement Social pour la Decennie 1990 to the Bank in the context of the second adjustment program. Following the appraisal of the Social Priorities Program, the strategy was updated, formally reendorsed by the new Government, and officially conveyed to the Bank [para. 6.01b]. Its internalization throughout the relevant agencies is now underway. Specific Sectoral Action Plans (SAPs) are being developed for the education and health sectors as part of the preparation of the Social Priorities Program. The recent creation of the Ministry of Population, which has the responsibilities of a ministry of planning, and should be able to coordinate actions throughout the social sectors within a unifying framework, is another signal that the Government is taking social concerns seriously and is adapting its institutions accordingly. Finally, the King's address to the Parliament of Morocco in October 1995 shows that concerns for the social situation now emanate from the highest levels of the power hierarchy. 2.04 Public resources for health are limited, and competition with other sectors for these resources is great. Moreover, considerable deficits have accumulated in the sector, and projected growing needs in the future (given population and demographic trends) will have to be addressed, while at the same time promoting efficiency and equity.
 -8 - 2.05 The Government has already taken a number of strategic measures to deal with these challenges: (a) resources will be targeted toward priority rural areas. The latest investment program already reflects this new policy, and the MSP's Programme de Medicalisation du Monde Rural is staffing rural health centers with physicians. Four-hundred physicians have already been deployed to priority districts; (b) the Government is also working on a health financing reform plan that would introduce compulsory health insurance. Discussions on establishing a fund to subsidize health care for the needy are also under way, but no agreement has as yet been reached on this important issue. At the same time, greater efficiency is being sought by reorganizing hospitals, granting them autonomy (SEGMA) and integrating priority health programs. These measures should also make it possible to channel more resources to the primary health level, as required in the SAP; (c) priority health programs will be strengthened, with special emphasis on programs in maternal and child health; and (d) roles and functions of the central and provincial levels will be redefined in the context of the recent reorganization of the MSP in order to give more autonomy to the provinces. The submission of the SAP was a condition of negotiations [para.6.02a]. B. Rationale for Bank Involvement 2.06 The severe state of degradation of Morocco's social sectors underscores the urgent need for intensive, durable action. Bank support for such action is called for both by the present climate of support in the Government and by the Bank's own Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), currently under preparation, which puts investing in people as its first priority. Bank support for the social sector would also accord with its parallel efforts to strengthen macroeconomic performance and encourage growth through private investment. Other donors have viewed the goals of the Strategie de Developpement Social pour la Decennie 1990 (based on the Living Standards Measurement Survey and confirmed by the World Bank poverty assessment) as a rallying point, and support for SDS policies is fully in line with the Bank's strategy of poverty alleviation and Morocco's overall plan to develop its human resources. Since the Bank has already financed several projects in Morocco's social sectors--especially in health and education--the proposed project would be an extension of earlier Bank involvement. The Country Economic Memorandum (World Bank 1995a) provides a solid body of evidence that programs whose aim is to improve Morocco's human capital base and to increase labor efficiency and productivity warrant reinforcement of present Bank support. Finally, a recent study of the region's present situation and long-term prospects (World Bank 1995b) shows that Morocco, along with its neighbors, is experiencing high unemployment and now feels an especially urgent need for bold programs aiming for both economic growth and poverty alleviation. The Bank's role in promoting the Government's social strategy and marshaling international and bilateral support for social programs will be critical if Morocco is to succeed in the fight it is waging against poverty, both in terms of equity and of economic growth. 2.07 In its SDS, the Government of Morocco identified inequity in the health 3ector as a major impediment to socioeconomic development and committed itself to channel more resources to rural areas, especially for the priority health programs (basic curative and preventive care, safe motherhood, transmissible diseases, nutrition). The proposed project would help the Government to
 -9 - close the gap between rural and urban health indicators by better targeting of the needy population. The project fits into the Bank's human resources development strategy, which supports efforts to improve the quality and relevance of social services, to increase public spending on basic services and improve targeting to underserved groups and areas and to increase internal efficiency overall within the human resources sector. Project preparation was instrumental in getting the MSP to develop its Sector Action Plan, which will provide a framework for all interventions in the health sector, facilitate coordination, and stimulate additional grant funding from other donors. C. Bank Experience and Lessons Learned 2.08 In the past, the Bank has supported several operations in Morocco's social sectors, and three such projects are currently being implemented (Rural Primary Education Project, Loan 3026- MOR; Rural Basic Education Development Project, Loan 3295-MOR; and Health Sector Investment Project, Loan 3171-MOR). The main general lessons to be drawn from these operations are as follows: (a) reforms in the social sectors should not be overly ambitious because of their immense impact on large groups and the political risks attached to them; (b) a good management information system and simple and transparent management, procurement, and disbursement procedures must be in place for all Bank-financed activities. Such measures are also meant to offset cumbersome local financing circuits, which tend to delay execution and slow down disbursements, especially for decentralized project activities. A study is currently being conducted by the Government to identify precisely the bottlenecks and the sources of delays; (c) to ensure full acceptance of the project, it is critical to seek the early involvement of all constituents--in particular, employees of line ministries at the provincial and local level who will play a crucial role during project implementation. Project Objectives 3.03 Specific objectives of this project are: (a) to provide better access to essential preventive and curative care from 47% (population currently living within 6 kms of an ESSB) to 60% of the targeted population, including equitable access to essential drugs; (b) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality in the targeted areas by increasing the coverage of prenatal visits from 28 to 50% and assisted deliveries in a medical setting from 18.5 to 30%, and by making available modern family planning methods; and (c) to maintain the performance of priority public health programs at the national level. Benefits 5.01 This project specifically targets the needy--especially women and children--and should therefore help transfer resources to those who need them most. Improving primary health care services in the target areas would benefit some 27% of Morocco's population, including 1.4 million
 - 26 - children under five and 1.05 million women of childbearing age. In addition, the overall population would benefit from the improved implementation of public health programs to control tuberculosis, malaria, cholera, leprosy, STDs, infectious ocular diseases as well as to improve hygiene and nutrition and to expand immunization coverage. Basic curative and preventive health coverage will increase from 47 to 60% in targeted areas. If adequately implemented, the project would significantly reduce the burden of disease in Morocco and would help reduce the number of maternal and child deaths and ensure more equity throughout the health system. 5.02 Following the burden-of-disease approach recommended in the World Development Report 1993: Investing in Health, a study is now being carried out in Morocco to assess the number of disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) that could be saved by the implementation of priority health programs [para. 4.08] and to identify cost-effective interventions. Rehabilitation of the primary health care system would also improve its quality, which would help to restore public confidence in the system. In the medium term this would stimulate demand for preventive care services. In addition, the reorganization of health administration and services already agreed upon [para. 6.01a] would improve the efficiency of the MSP and maximize the impact of the proposed project's health activities. The implementation of the Sector Action Plan initiated during project preparation would further help to ensure better coordination of aid, and would provide a planning and monitoring tool for the MSP. Finally, the integration of health with education and other basic services would result in cross sectoral synergy. B. Risks 5.03 The first risk relates to the potentially weak implementing capacity of MSP, especially at the provincial level, given the fact that, under the proposed project, provincial health officials would have the primary responsibility for planning, implementing and monitoring activities in the targeted provinces. To address this risk, MSP is currently in the process of reorganizing the provincial level in order to strengthen its managerial capabilities. In addition, during negotiations, agreement wa reached on identification and implementation of mechanisms which will strengthen provincial participation to planning and decision-making [para. 6.03a(iii)]. The second risk relates to the possibility that Morocco may fail to implement the hospital reforms and the financing strategy being developed under the Health Management Project, to reorganize at the provincial level and to implement the actions proposed for the public pharmaceutical sector. Such situation would threaten the sustainability of the entire health system over the long term, since it would effectively prevent adequate shifting of resources to the needy, rural population and to more cost-effective interventions. These activities are well underway and unlikely to be stopped. In addition, financing of drugs under the project is linked to a set of dated covenants [para.6.03a(ii)]. The third risk is linked to the lack of adequate counterpart funding, especially for recurrent costs. doc.repnme: Morocco - Social Priorities Program : Basic Health Project
doc.abstracts: Specific objectives of the Basic Health Project under the Social Priorities Program/Barnamaj al Aoulaouiyat al Ijtimaiya program (SPP/BAJ) are: 1) to provide a better access to essential preventive and curative care from 47 to 60 percent of the targeted population, including equitable access to essential drugs; 2) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality in the targeted areas by increasing the coverage of prenatal visits from 28 to 50 percent and assisted deliveries in a medical setting from 18.5 to 30 percent, and by making available modern family planning methods; and 3) to maintain the performance of priority public health programs at the national level. The project will consist of the following three components: 1) increase in access to essential curative and preventive health care in the thirteen provinces targeted under the project; 2) strengthening of the safe motherhood program in all its aspects within the thirteen provinces; and 3) continuing support for priority health programs nationwide.
